Award.AwardTitle: The Power of Images: A Computational Investigation of Political Mobilization via Social Media

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
General Abstract
Social media have been described by some scholars as a "weapon of the weak." Any person in the world with a mobile device and network connection can now communicate with a potential audience of unlimited size. This project proposes the first large-scale study of the roll of images in the social media communications of advocacy organizations, social protest movements, and extremist militant groups. The team will collect social media communications in real time and exploit recent "deep learning" advances from computer science to automatically label millions of images for objects (crowds, animals, weapons etc.), entities (specific actors), and emotions evoked (fear, sadness, humor, etc.). The team seeks to assess whether, all else equal, these images promote political message engagement and diffusion.

Technical Abstract
Research in psychology finds that images are easier for individuals to process cognitively, and have a larger impact on consciousness than do words. Images should be especially important tools for traditionally marginalized groups that rely on outsider strategies to promote issue awareness and their views. This is new ground however, as there is no theory and no databases for studying the mobilizing effects of political social media communications. The research team will construct new social media databases for a wide range of political groups. The project will contribute new labeled political image collections to existing computer science image repositories. The team also proposes to offer national workshops on advanced image classification methods for social scientists, and will disseminate research findings to scholars and practitioners through conference presentations and peer-reviewed publications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Vibrant democracies depend on robust political participation. Social media have been described as ?weapons of the weak? because they enable any person in the world with a mobile device and network connection to communicate with an unlimited potential audience. Groups pursuing ?outside? political strategies believe that social media help them to increase issue awareness and promote their views. But how do these groups use social media effectively to advance their causes? We are studying the mobilizing power of images in  social media communications. Psychological research demonstrates that images can have more impact on attention and behavior than words.  We ask whether messaging efforts that include images are more effective, and if so, what types of images are most effective?  

This subject of the mobilizing power of images has received little attention to date. We examine it by collecting millions of social media messages in real time from a large number of public organizations and individuals. We then use ?deep learning? methods developed by computer scientists to automatically label the images in these messages for content, before statistically comparing social media messages that were shared more frequently (typically messages related to a salient political issue) to those that were not. We are especially interested in the emotions that images evoke, and which emotions are most likely to lead readers to share a message, or to begin following an organization?s social media account.

Our work on this ambitious project continues and we are grateful for the NSF support we have received.  To date we have published a book to teach other social scientists how to use automated image labeling methods in their own research, and one peer review article examining the effectiveness of social media communications in the wake of the Marjorie Stoneman Douglas High School Shooting. We are currently working on another paper that shows how unsupervised machine learning methods that are commonly used to explore large volumes of text can also be effectively used to explore large image collections.

In terms of broader impacts, our interest in evoked emotions is original and we anticipate that it will inspire follow up research in the field of computer vision methods (where most of the focus to date has been on object recognition). We also expect that our findings will be of value to public organizations that are trying to gain attention to their causes. Finally, this project has created numerous opportunities for graduate student training. The graduate students who have worked on this project are now employed as professors, post-doctoral researchers and programmers. It has also created paid research opportunities for numerous undergraduates, and helped to inspire at least one to pursue a Ph.D.
